all_paragraphs: MS SQL Server developers and DBMS administrators both know that text formatting takes a lot of time in your coding process. Also, formatting is often superficial or even completely absent. Things get even more complicated because everyone does formatting differently and there is no unified style. All of this leads to situations in which one specialist will spend a lot of time to understand the code written by another specialist.

I can tell from my own experience that it usually takes a few years to establish a set of formatting rules. The main issue with developing and applying such standards on the scale of the whole company, or even some part of the company, mostly comes down to the fact that it’s really difficult for a person to learn to write code differently. A lot of resistance can also be felt during code review because the specialists maintaining the code do not always agree with the formatting rules. In practice, it is very difficult to maintain these standards manually, without a special tool.

When you have special code formatting software, you can set your own formatting standard through it or just use the default one. In this way, all code will be formatted automatically from this point on. As a result, you won’t need to spend time on script formatting and review of the formatting.
Usually, the standardization process has the following lifecycle:
The initial standard is often taken from the default one in the chosen tool — in this way, steps 3–4 won’t be cycled and step 5 will be solved at the same time.
In some companies, step 3 isn’t achieved, so the specialists decide how to write code on their own. This significantly complicates the development process, code maintenance, and introducing changes.
You can divide the process of a company evolving its code standardization into 3 stages:
1. There is no standard, everyone writes code as they want
2. There is a standard, but it’s maintained manually
3. There is a standard and it’s maintained automatically
Based on my observations, we can show the increase of development and maintenance speed between the three main stages like this:
This table estimates the average amount of time spent on development, maintenance and case transfers.
You can automate the maintenance of the standard with special tools — such tools can either be custom-written or just chosen from available third-party solutions.
Sooner or later, database specialists realize that formatting standardization is crucial if you want all developers to understand the code better. You can find both paid and free solutions for this.
In this article, we’ll look at one of these tools — SQL Complete for MS SQL Server. Currently, this tool integrates with SSMS and Visual Studio. It is also built into dbForge Studio for SQL Server.
